text.p: The following are the main stories from Wednesday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG
- Ukraine wants same treatment as Russia from West
- Governing coalition parties reject opposition Social Democrats' (SPD) tax plans
- Foreign Minister Kinkel wonders about Boris Yeltsin's health
- Construction investment falls
- Bavarian retail industry clinches pay deal which may be model for other regions
- Finance Minister Waigel says privatisation programme should not be rushed
- Industrial output unchanged in July from a year earlier
- Volkswagen VW decides not to take up controversial state subsidies for now
HANDELSBLATT
- Construction industry says situation in east Germany is catastrophic
- Volkswagen VW decides not to take up controversial state subsidies for now
- Tax inspectors investigate WestLB on suspicion of helping customers to evade tax
- Waigel urges municipalities and federal states to press ahead with privatisation programme
- Deutsche Bank may face heavy losses in London
- Bahlsen families split
- Gas industry does not believe planned liberalisation will bring promised benefits
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG
- Waigel rejects SPD tax proposals
- Czech President Havel says German side is holding up joint declaration of post-war reconciliation
- Tax inspectors investigate WestLB on suspicion of helping customers to evade tax
- German firms get 500 million marks of orders in Ukraine
- Industrial output barely rises in July
- Wholesale turnover up in July
- Bonn to sell off its airport stakes
DIE WELT
- Compromise possible in row with EU over VW subsidies
- Bavarian retail industry pay deal may be model for other regions
- Interior Minister expects to sign agreement with Serbia next week on repatriation of refugees
- Economics Minister Rexrodt attacks state premier Biedenkopf over VW subsidies
- Tax inspectors investigate WestLB on suspicion of helping customers to evade tax
- Construction industry wants public sector to invest more to create jobs
- German companies in Ukraine feel neglected by Chancellor Kohl
-- Bonn Newsroom +49 228 2609760
